Knowledge Point: Ordinary possessive constructions, the most common possessive construction type, are made by attaching a possessive suffix to the possessed (the head noun in the NP), as illustrated in~(\ref{exe:posssuff}).

Three other, much less common constructions are available. First, possessive pronouns can be used as modifiers of the possessed head noun in the NP to create a possessive construction. The possessive pronouns occur adnominally only rarely, and mostly following the kinship\is{kinship} terms esa `father' and ema `mother' as in~(\ref{exe:posspron}). Second, a combination of a possessive suffix on the possessed noun and a possessive pronoun following the possessed noun also creates a possessive construction, as in~(\ref{exe:possdouble}). Third, a combination of pronoun, possessed noun and possessive suffix is found, as illustrated in~(\ref{exe:pusunrasa}).

The freestanding possessive pronouns can be used both as NP heads and as modifiers, whereas the suffixes always have to be attached to the NP head (the possessed noun). Adnominal use of the freestanding possessive pronoun was illustrated in~(\ref{exe:posspron}) and~(\ref{exe:possdouble}) above. A pronominal example is given in~(\ref{exe:anggonawa}).
Content 3: \gll \textbf{anggon}=a wa lolok tak-karuok | \gls 1SG.POSS=FOC PROX leaf CLF_LEAF-three | \glt `This is mine. It has three leaves.'

Section: Possessive constructions with nominal possessors\is{possessor-possessum order
Knowledge Point: In possessive constructions with nominal possessors, the NP head (the possessed noun) is preceded by the possessor. It is ungrammatical to swap the order. The third-person possessive marker is suffixed to the NP head, as shown in~(\ref{exe:malikkeweun}) and~(\ref{exe:emadidirasun}).

Section: Possessive constructions with nominal possessors\is{possessor-possessum order
Knowledge Point: Note also the contrasting meaning between~(\ref{exe:childdog}), where bal `dog' is the NP head, and~(\ref{exe:dogchild}), where tumun `child' is the head.
Content 1: \gll tumun bal-un | \gls child dog-3POSS | \glt `The child's dog.'
Content 2: \gll bal tumun-un | \gls dog child-3POSS | \glt `The dog's child (puppy).'

Section: Possessive constructions with nominal possessors\is{possessor-possessum order
Knowledge Point: NPs may be embedded in prenominal possessor position to modify the NP head. In~(\ref{exe:temankeweun}), the head sanong `roof' is modified by kewe `house', which is in turn modified by `friend'.

Section: Possessive constructions with nominal possessors\is{possessor-possessum order
Knowledge Point: Although both third-person possession and nominalised attributes are marked with the suffix -un (see §\ref{sec:nomder}), there is no ambiguity between a possessive phrase with an attribute, as in~(\ref{exe:possnom}a), and a phrase with a nominalised attribute, as in~(\ref{exe:possnom}b).

The most common possessive construction is created by means of the possessive suffix. I refer to this as the basic possessive construction. This construction can be used for both animate and inanimate possessors and possessed. See~(\ref{exe:tumunan}) with tumun `child' and~(\ref{exe:dowiwe}) with dowi `seed' as the possessed, respectively.
Content 1: \gll an bo lembaga nerun tumun-\textbf{an} se bo temun | \gls 1SG go prison inside child-1SG.POSS IAM go big | \glt `I went to prison, and my child has grown big.'
Content 2: \gll nain dowi-\textbf{pe} opa me | \gls like seed-1PL.POSS ANA TOP | \glt `Like those seeds of ours.'

Knowledge Point: There are a number of conventionalised constructions that can or must be made by means of the third-person possessive suffix -un. First, teknonyms, a common term of address, are made with this possessive suffix. Teknonyms\is{names!teknonymy} are formed with the name of a firstborn and follow the template [name] [kinship term]-[un], where the kinship term can be esa `father', ema `mother' or tara- `grandparent'. Consider~(\ref{exe:nyongemun}) and~(\ref{exe:diantaraun}). Note that esa and ema are esun and emun, respectively, when inflected with the third-person possessive suffix -un.
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Dian} \textbf{tara-un=a} Pakpak=a bot=kin | \gls Dian grandparent-3POSS=FOC Fakfak=FOC go=VOL | \glt `Dian's grandfather wants to go to Fakfak.'

Knowledge Point: Second, part-whole relations may be made with -un, illustrated in~(\ref{exe:partwholes}). The suffix -un attaches to the base.

Third, geographical names\is{names!place names} may make use of a construction with third-person possessive -un. On the island where Kalamang is spoken, each coastal area around a bay has a name. Several landscape features are associated with this name. Thus, the area of Tat includes Tat Os `Tat Beach' and Tat Karimun `Cape Tat'. Two landscape features are inflected with -un when they follow a geographical name: wilak `sea', given in~(\ref{exe:wilaun}) and kelek `mountain; inland', illustrated in~(\ref{exe:keleun}).
Content 1: \gll Sek wilak-\textbf{un} metko tebolsuban | \gls Sek sea-3POSS DIST.LOC fish_at_reef_edge | \glt `[She] went fishing at Sek's sea.'
Content 2: \gll ma Sabaor=ka kasawari=at sarie Sabaor kelek-\textbf{un}=ka | \gls 3SG Sabaor=LAT cassowary=OBJ chase Sabaor inland-3POSS=LAT | \glt `He chased the cassowary from Sabaor, from Sabaor inland.'

Section: Possessive constructions with a freestanding possessive pronoun
Knowledge Point: The corpus contains ten different nouns that are followed by freestanding possessive pronouns. Six of these nouns are also found with a possessive suffix, which means they do not require a possessive pronoun construction.\footnote{These are pendapat `opinion' (Malay loan), toman `bag', hak `right' (Malay loan), kewe `house', asal `origin' (Malay loan) and guru `teacher' (Malay loan). A reason that many of these are Malay loans might be that possessive constructions in Papuan Malay are made with a periphrastic construction (possessor + `have' + possessum), which might trigger the use of a possessive pronoun instead of a suffix in Kalamang. In any case, the number of occurrences of these words is so low in comparison to those of esa `father' and ema `mother' that we will not consider them any further.} Wowa `aunt' and tata `grandfather' are not found with a possessive suffix, but are uncommon in the corpus. Esa `father' and ema `mother' are only found with a third-person possessive suffix, and only in teknonyms, as in~(\ref{exe:nyongemun}) and~(\ref{exe:diantaraun}) above (see also §\ref{sec:names}).
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Dian} \textbf{tara-un=a} Pakpak=a bot=kin | \gls Dian grandparent-3POSS=FOC Fakfak=FOC go=VOL | \glt `Dian's grandfather wants to go to Fakfak.'

Section: Possessive constructions with a freestanding possessive pronoun
Knowledge Point: Examples of esa `father' and ema `mother' followed by a possessive pronoun are given in~(\ref{exe:esainggon}) and~(\ref{exe:emakain}), respectively.
Content 1: \gll esa \textbf{inggon} to esa \textbf{anggon} ma don-pat | \gls father 1PL.EXCL.POSS right father 1SG.POSS 3SG clothing-sew | \glt `Our father, right, my father, he sewed clothing.'
Content 2: \gll o in ema \textbf{kain}=at konat=nin | \gls EMPH 1PL.EXCL mother 2SG.POSS=OBJ see=NEG | \glt `O, we didn't see your mother.'

Section: Possessive constructions with a freestanding possessive pronoun
Knowledge Point: At this point, it is unclear whether other kinship\is{kinship} terms also require a possessive pronoun.\footnote{There is no restriction against a possessive suffix on a noun ending in /a/, cf. nika-an `my fishing line'.} Besides three occurrences of tata `grandfather' and one of wowa `aunt', there are no possessive constructions with other kinship terms. The only exception to this is the five inalienable\is{alienability} terms mentioned in §\ref{sec:posssuf}, which must carry a possessive suffix, as well as tumun `child', which may carry a possessive suffix, as was illustrated in~(\ref{exe:tumunan}) above. What is clear, however, is that words from the same semantic class (kinship terms) may behave differently with respect to possessive constructions. This also shows that alienability of the possessed does not play a role in the choice of a possessive construction, as is common elsewhere in East Indonesia \parencite[see e.g.][]{klamer2008}. Note that kinship terms are also treated differently from other nouns in possessive constructions in other languages, notably Italian and Scandinavian \parencite{delsing2002}.
Content 1: \gll an bo lembaga nerun tumun-\textbf{an} se bo temun | \gls 1SG go prison inside child-1SG.POSS IAM go big | \glt `I went to prison, and my child has grown big.'

Knowledge Point: A noun marked with a possessive suffix may be followed by a possessive pronoun. I refer to this as double (possessive) marking. It is unclear what the function of this kind of double constructions is. There is one example in the corpus with the same noun taman/teman `friend' used once with double marking, given in~(\ref{exe:tamanunmain}), and several times with just the suffix (an example is given in~\ref{exe:tamanun}).

It is tempting to analyse the double-marked nouns as receiving extra prominence – for example, to contrast the referent with another referent – but there is no evidence for this. In~(\ref{exe:tamanunmain}), the speaker picks up a picture and identifies who is in it. It is true that the referent is placed in \is{focus}focus (with focus marker =a on the possessive pronoun), but this could also have been achieved by placing the focus marker on the possessive suffix. There is no contrast between two people with a friend in this context.

It is rare for a noun marked with a possessive suffix to be followed by a possessive pronoun. The corpus has around ten examples. It should be noted that, as with the majority of the nouns marked with just a possessive pronoun, many nouns that have double marking are Malay loanwords. As speculated above, the fact that Papuan Malay uses a periphrastic possessive construction may trigger the use of the possessive pronoun in Kalamang. However, this does not explain the use of a possessive suffix on top of that. (\ref{exe:inja}) shows that the double construction also occurs with indigenous Kalamang words like in `name'.

A possessive suffix and a freestanding possessive pronoun may also be adjacent when the suffix and the pronoun designate different referents. This can happen when the suffix is needed to make a compound, such as `foot-print' in~(\ref{exe:korter}). The possessive pronoun is then needed to indicate the possessor of the footprint. This is very rare: only two examples exist in the corpus.
Content 1: \gll an me kor-an=a di=kor-ter-\textbf{un} \textbf{main}=ko | \gls 1SG TOP foot-1SG.POSS=FOC CAUS=foot-mark-3POSS 3POSS=LOC | \glt `As for me, I put my foot in his footprints.'

Knowledge Point: Other examples of spatial association are the names of certain species, especially fish species, as shown in~(\ref{exe:wienart}). The wienar `parrotfish' is contrasted with other wienar species, such as wienar saruam `longnose parrotfish'. It can also be used in a more general sense to group for example all fish found close to the shore, as in~(\ref{exe:sorkis}).

=kin can also express general (associative) ownership without specifying the possessor. This can be used, for example, with the question word naman `who', as in~(\ref{exe:namankin}). The answer to this question also contains =kin, marking the possession of a group of people. Thus, naman=kin functions as a \is{placeholder}placeholder for Dian taraun mu=kin. The answer also contains the third-person plural pronoun mu used as an associative plural.\is{associative plural}
Content 1: \gll Dian tara-un mu=\textbf{kin} | \gls Dian grandfather-3POSS 3SG=POSS | \glt `Dian's grandfather's and associates'.'

Knowledge Point: This same marking of the possession of a group, often used with teknonyms\is{names!teknonymy} (see §\ref{sec:names}), is also illustrated in~(\ref{exe:ass}).
Content 1: \gsrc Pertama nebainggo, Sainudinkin. Sainudinkin lewat, a terus menggara Kiba mukin. | \gls pertama neba=\textbf{kin}=ko sainudin=\textbf{kin} sainudin=\textbf{kin} lewat a terus mengga=ta kiba mu=\textbf{kin} | \gls first PH-POSS=LOC Sainudin-POSS Sainudin=POSS pass INT further DIST.LAT={\glta} Kiba 3PL=POSS\\

Knowledge Point: Interestingly, because =kin is attached to the last element of the NP, it can also be attached to a possessive pronoun. In~(\ref{exe:esakainkin}), the use of =kin (instead of third-person possessive -un) signals that the possessed item, some fishing equipment, belongs to the father's household and not to him personally.
Content 1: \gll mera ge [esa kain]=\textbf{kin} mera ki napaki=ta | \gls then not father 2SG.POSS=POSS then 2PL use=NFIN | \glt `If not, you can use your father's.'

Knowledge Point: In~(\ref{exe:konkin}), =kin attaches to a numeral, which refers to the price of a certain size of fishing line (the word nika `line' is elided). =kin indicates that the numeral is representative of a type.
Content 1: \gll ripi putkon=\textbf{kin} me minggi winyal | \gls thousand ten=POSS TOP DIST.INS sail_fish | \glt `With [fishing line of the kind that costs] ten thousand [you go] fishing while sailing around.'

Knowledge Point: Lastly, =kin is used by one speaker in two recordings about canoe building to refer to parts of the canoe. In~(\ref{exe:tantayonkin}), the left and right side of the canoe are described, and either side is marked with =kin. In~(\ref{exe:ass3}), the canoes are the parts, and the whole is a tree from which three canoes are cut. An alternative analysis is that these uses of =kin do not indicate a part-whole relationship, but that there is an understood nominal referent with which =kin expresses an associative relationship. In~(\ref{exe:tantayonkin}), this could be the drill holes (the left side's drill holes), and in~(\ref{exe:ass3}), the wood or the motor boat's base.
Content 1: \gll tantayon=\textbf{kin} di=saran=i koyet koi tanbes=\textbf{kin}=at koi bor=taet | \gls left=POSS CAUS=ascend=PLNK finish then right=POSS=OBJ then drill=again | \glt `After putting up the left side, we drill the right side again.'
Content 2: \gll koi et mir-eir=\textbf{kin}=at kon-i potma raor=\textbf{kin}=at potma limabelas=\textbf{kin}=at potma koi et pokpok=\textbf{kin} kon | \gls then canoe CLF_CANOE-two=POSS=OBJ one-OBJQNT cut middle=POSS=OBJ cut 15_hp_motor_boat.MLY=POSS=OBJ cut then canoe small_motor_boat=POSS one | \glt `Then [I] cut one canoe from two, cut it in the middle, cut a motor boat, then a small motorboat is one.'
Content 3: \gll tantayon=\textbf{kin} di=saran=i koyet koi tanbes=\textbf{kin}=at koi bor=taet | \gls left=POSS CAUS=ascend=PLNK finish then right=POSS=OBJ then drill=again | \glt `After putting up the left side, we drill the right side again.'
Content 4: \gll koi et mir-eir=\textbf{kin}=at kon-i potma raor=\textbf{kin}=at potma limabelas=\textbf{kin}=at potma koi et pokpok=\textbf{kin} kon | \gls then canoe CLF_CANOE-two=POSS=OBJ one-OBJQNT cut middle=POSS=OBJ cut 15_hp_motor_boat.MLY=POSS=OBJ cut then canoe small_motor_boat=POSS one | \glt `Then [I] cut one canoe from two, cut it in the middle, cut a motor boat, then a small motorboat is one.'
